2025-05-04 00:27:29,921 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Monetary Authority of Singapore\'s monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: mas core inflation is now projected to be between 3.0–4.0% this year, up from the earlier forecast of 2.5–3.5%.\n                "}]

\\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: further, we will shift the policy band from that of a zero percent appreciation to one of modest and gradual appreciation.\n                "}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates a shift to a policy of modest and gradual appreciation of the Singapore dollar, which suggests a tighter monetary policy stance."
}

involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: against this backdrop and in view of the sharp fall in domestic economic output over the past two quarters, singapore’s gdp growth forecast for 2009 has been lowered to between -9% and -6%.\n                "}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: for 2008 and 2009 the singapore economy has weakened over the course of 2008, alongside an escalation in the turmoil in financial markets and a more severe deceleration in global economic activity.\n                "}]

talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in comparison, the domestic-oriented sectors should continue to provide some support to the economy, underpinned by sustained demand for healthcare and education services, as well as public infrastructure spending.\n                "}]

Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: finally, water charges were also raised in july as part of a 4-year (1997-2000) plan to promote water conservation, while tobacco saw a hike in excise duty in march.. as we are a price taker importing all our oil, we cannot shield ourselves from price fluctuations in world markets.\n                "}]

Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: overall, major uncertainty remains.\n                "}]

inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in the us, the recovery in the labour market will continue to support consumer spending, which should bring about some pickup in corporate capital expenditure, including in business it upgrading.\n                "}]

If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the recovery in the global economy will depend on the epidemiological course of the pandemic and the efficacy of policy responses.\n                "}]

Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: furthermore, as the economic uncertainty arising from the september 11 incident had diminished and financial markets had stabilised, the exchange rate policy band was narrowed.\n                "}]

If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the slowdown was largely anticipated and driven by weaker activity in the manufacturing and modern services sectors, which had posted strong outturns in the preceding quarter.\n                "}]

"justification": "The sentence discusses the slowdown in manufacturing and modern services sectors, which is not related to monetary policy decisions or stances."

Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n 2025-05-04 00:28:11,987 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Monetary Authority of Singapore\'s monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: both upside and downside risks to the inflation remain.\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the existence of both upside and downside risks to inflation, but does not suggest any action or stance on monetary policy."
}

Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the singapore economy is expected to grow at a more moderate pace this year following several years of robust expansion.\n                "}]

talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{mas}{six} Exchange rate policy, Inflation control, Employment, Trade, Foreign labor and Talent attraction, and Global Supply Chain Hub.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange Rate Policy}: A sentence pertaining to changes such as the appreciation or depreciation of the value of the Singapore dollar (SGD).\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation Control}: A sentence pertaining to adjusting the inflationary pressure by weakening or strengthening the SGD.\n    \\item \\emph{Employment}: A sentence pertaining to changes in the employment sectors.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations between Singapore and a foreign country. If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n    \n\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Monetary Authority of Singapore}} \\label{tb:mas_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Exchange Rate Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & Favoring stricter trade policies and protective measures to guard domestically produced items against international competition. & Favoring open markets and more relaxed policies to boost exports and secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the slowdown was generally broad based as external shocks were transmitted to the domestic economy via both the financial and trade channels.\n                "}]

"justification": "The sentence discusses the transmission of external shocks to the domestic economy, which is not related to monetary policy decisions or stances."

Policy} & In favor of or advocating for the appreciation of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & In favor of or advocating for the depreciation or weakening of the Singapore dollar (SGD). & Identifying economic trends but not suggestive of action to the currency. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation Control} & Favoring a stronger SGD to reduce inflationary pressures. & Tending towards weakening or maintaining the SGD due to the reduction of inflationary pressures. & Discusses inflation as a whole and mentions statistics but don’t take a stance on it. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Employment} & Lack of employment due to the strengthening of the SGD due to other concerns. & Favoring a weaker SGD to boost export-driven employment sectors. & Discusses employment metrics without suggesting action either way. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade} & secure Singapore’s role as a trade hub. & Discusses previous trade strategies or options for future opportunities. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Labor Policy} & Sentences discuss the need for stricter immigration policies in order to keep local jobs and limit foreign labor. & Suggesting the allowing of an increase in foreign talent in the local markets to foster innovation and economic growth. & Discusses the maintaining of immigration policies and SGD or mentioning local vs. foreign labor forces. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Global Supply Chain} & Suggesting the mitigation of global supply chain disruptions by focusing on more local sourcing. & Sentences implies the increase in involvement in global supply chain in order to enhance Singapore’s position as a hub and to invite investment. & Maintaining Signapore’s policy and involvement in the global supply chain due to the lack of concerns of disruptions or happiness with Singapore’s place as the hub. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: a number of leading indicators have recently picked up slightly, and consumption spending has held up somewhat better than expected, particularly in the us.\n                "}]

If not discussing Singapore, we label irrelevant.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Labor and Talent Attraction}: A sentence that discusses changes in immigration policies to increase or limit foreign talent.\n    \\item \\emph{Global Supply Chain Hub}: A sentence that discusses Singapore's involvement in the global supply chain.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``To combat rising inflation, the central bank may need to steepen the exchange rate band.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Increasing the exchange rate band indicates a tighter monetary policy stance to maintain price stability.\n    \n    \\item ``A flattening of the band would provide greater flexibility during economic downturns.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Flattening the exchange rate band indicates a more accommodative stance to support the economy.\n\n    \\item ``The current monetary policy remains effective without any proposed changes.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: There are no changes made to the monetary policy and remains neutral.\n    \n    \\item ``The committee discussed the impact of the weather on agricultural output, which is irrelevant to monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: Agricultural output does not have an impact on the monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``External inflationary pressures are likely to stay muted for the rest of 2003.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The statement suggests that inflationary pressures are not expected to worsen, thereby creating room for expansionary monetary policy.\n\n    \\item ``MAS will be shifting the schedule of its semi-annual cycle from January/July to April/October.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence relates to an operational or scheduling change and does not mention monetary policy decisions or stances.\n
